title: Terminal Intermediate
description: More powerful terminal commands for everyday development

cards.task: Search for files named '*.json' in the current directory and subdirectories
cards.description: Recursively searches for files matching a pattern
cards.whenToUse: When you need to find files by name or pattern
scenarios: You're looking for all JSON config files in a project
You need to find a file but don't remember which folder it's in
You want to see all files of a certain type

cards.task: Search for the text 'TODO' in all files in the current directory
cards.description: Searches for text patterns inside files recursively
cards.whenToUse: When you need to find specific text within files
scenarios: You're looking for all TODO comments in your code
You need to find where a function is used
You want to find all files containing an error message

cards.task: Show the first 10 lines of a file called 'log.txt'
cards.description: Displays the beginning of a file (default 10 lines)
cards.whenToUse: When you want to preview the start of a large file
scenarios: You want to check the header of a CSV file
You need to see the beginning of a log file
You want to peek at a file without opening the whole thing

cards.task: Show the last 20 lines of a file called 'log.txt'
cards.description: Displays the end of a file with a specified number of lines
cards.whenToUse: When you need to see the most recent entries in a file
scenarios: You want to see the latest log entries
You need to check recent errors in a log file
You want to see how a file ends

cards.task: Watch a log file for new entries in real-time
cards.description: Continuously displays new lines as they're added to a file
cards.whenToUse: When you want to monitor a file that's being updated
scenarios: You're watching server logs while testing
You want to see errors as they happen
You're debugging and need to monitor output

cards.task: Create nested directories 'projects/clasp/my-app' in one command
cards.description: Creates a directory and any necessary parent directories
cards.whenToUse: When you need to create multiple nested folders at once
scenarios: You're setting up a project structure
You need to create a deep folder path
You want to create folders without checking if parents exist

cards.task: Delete a directory and all its contents
cards.description: Forcefully removes a directory and everything inside it (use with caution!)
cards.whenToUse: When you need to delete a folder that contains files
scenarios: You're removing an old project folder
You need to clean up a failed installation
You want to start fresh by deleting everything

cards.task: Copy a directory and all its contents to a new location
cards.description: Recursively copies a directory and all files inside
cards.whenToUse: When you need to duplicate an entire folder
scenarios: You want to back up a project folder
You're creating a copy of a project to experiment with
You need to duplicate a template folder

cards.task: Show disk usage of the current directory
cards.description: Displays the total size of a directory in human-readable format
cards.whenToUse: When you want to know how much space a folder is using
scenarios: You're checking how big your project has grown
You need to find what's taking up disk space
You want to compare folder sizes

cards.task: Run two commands in sequence (second runs only if first succeeds)
cards.description: Chains commands so the second only runs if the first exits successfully
cards.whenToUse: When you want to run commands in sequence with error checking
scenarios: You want to cd into a directory and then run a command
You need to build and then deploy only if build succeeds
You're chaining git add and git commit

cards.task: Redirect command output to a file (overwrite)
cards.description: Sends the output of a command to a file, replacing any existing content
cards.whenToUse: When you want to save command output to a file
scenarios: You want to save a directory listing to a file
You need to capture error output for debugging
You're generating a report from command output

cards.task: Append command output to a file (without overwriting)
cards.description: Adds the output of a command to the end of a file
cards.whenToUse: When you want to add to an existing file without erasing it
scenarios: You're building up a log file over multiple runs
You want to append data to a config file
You're collecting output from multiple commands

cards.description: Displays the value of an environment variable
cards.whenToUse: When you need to check or debug environment variables
scenarios: You want to see where the system looks for commands
You're debugging why a command isn't found
You need to check if a path is in your PATH variable

cards.task: Find which program runs when you type a command (e.g., 'node')
cards.description: Shows the full path to an executable
cards.whenToUse: When you want to know which version of a program is being used
scenarios: You have multiple versions installed and want to know which one runs
You're debugging path issues
You want to confirm a program is installed

cards.description: Lists all running processes with details
cards.whenToUse: When you need to see what's running on your system
scenarios: You want to find a process that's using too much CPU
You need to find the process ID to kill a stuck program
You're checking if a server is running
